Ledningssystemets omfattning är samma som de anställda som omfattas av regelverket.

question.text: I SS-ISO/IEC 27002 används begreppet Informationsäkerhetsspolicy medan det i 27001 står policy för LIS. Hur kan en policy för LIS förhålla sig till informationssäkerhetspolicyn enligt standarden?

course.question: En policy för LIS är ett separat dokument som styrs av verksamhetens regler för ledningens kontroll av systemet och förhåller sig inte alls till informationssäkerhetspolicyn.> En LIS-policy kan vara ett internt dokument som utgår från informationssäkerhetspolicyn men är mer detaljerad. Eftersom SS-ISO/IEC 27002 bara är en guidestandard med bör krav så är förhållandet mellan dem "bör" i informationssäker- hetspolicyn och "skall" i policyn för LIS. Förhållandet är att det skall finnas två dokument för att följa både SS-ISO/IEC 27001 och 27002: en LIS- policy och en informationssäkerhetspolicy.

question.text: Vad är mindre lämpligt för att strukturera organisationen för informationssäkerhet?
question.answer: IT är ansvariga för informationssäkerheten.
Det finns en tydlig rollfördelning så att krav och uppfyllnad kan fördelas.
Verksamheten har en tydlig påverkan på informationssäkerheten.
Det finns en tydlig koppling mellan ledning och hur ansvaret fördelas i organisationen.
Det finns en speciell roll som har hand om informations-säkerhetsfrågor som har direkt koppling till ledningen.

question.text:
Nedanstående klartext är krypterad med Vigenére. Vilket är lösenordet?

Kryptotext: NBJP YVDXKÖ JPZM
question.answer: BURK
KAKA

question.text: Vad är definitionen av en händelse i ett IT system?
question.answer: En händelse i ett system (t.ex dator eller nätverkskomponent) är en skadlig påverkan.
En händelse i ett system (t.ex dator eller nätverkskomponent) är en ofarlig incident.
En händelse i ett system (t.ex dator eller nätverkskomponent) är något som man kan utläsa från ett loggsystem.
En händelse i ett system (t.ex dator eller nätverkskomponent) är en incident.
En händelse i ett system (t.ex dator eller nätverkskomponent) är en påverkan i det systemet.
Ett penetrationstest är ett försök att förbigå säkerhet i nätverk/system/applikationer med samma tekniker som en hacker skulle använda.
Genom manipulation av personer försöka få åtkomst till lokaler eller system.
Ett sätt att göra en beräkning hur mycket IT angrepp kostar organisationen.
Är ett sätt att testa medarbetarnas säkerhetsmedvetande.
Ny standard för IT incidenthantering.
Sökning efter bevis av bristfälliga A: Licensavtal. B: Rutiner. C: Säkerhetskopior.
Sökning efter bevis av förändringar i A: Loggar. B: Binärer. C: Brandväggsregler.
Sökning efter bevis för sårbara A: Datorer. B: Användare. C: Inbrottsskydd.
Sökning efter bevis för sårbara A: Mjukvaruversioner. B: Felkonfiguration. C: Patchnivå.
Sökning efter bevis för A: Virus. B: Trojaner. C: Gästkonton.

question.text: Vem tillfaller upphovsrätten enligt upphovsrättslagen (URL) när en beställare anlitar en leverantör med anställda programmerare för att utveckla (skräddarsy) en programvara som endast ska användas av beställaren och dennes organisation?
question.answer: Leverantören, eftersom de som skapar programvaran är anställda av denne och inga rättigheter övergår till beställaren eller kvarstannar hos de anställda om det inte uttryckligen avtalats.
Leverantörens anställda, eftersom det är de personer som skapat programvaran som är upphovsmän och därmed tillfaller rättigheterna dem.
Beställaren, eftersom denne har betalat för utvecklingen och att rättigheterna därmed blir dennes.

question.text: Om vår organisation behandlar personuppgifter - genom anställda eller konsulter - vem är då personuppgiftsansvarig enligt PuL och bl.a. är ansvarig för att personuppgifterna behandlas på ett korrekt sätt?
question.answer: Den anställde i vår organisation som har fått sin arbetsuppgift att sköta personuppgiftsbehandlingen får ansvaret genom sin befattning.
Den konsult eller dennes arbetsgivare som vi anlitat för att behandla våra personuppgifter får ansvaret om vi avtalar om det.
Det är alltid vi (d.v.s vår ledning) som ansvarar, eftersom det alltid är vi som bestämmer ändamålen med behandlingen och ansvaret kan inte överföras.

question.text: Vilket av följande är korrekt när det gäller hur vår IT-policy kan bidra till att vi uppfyller vad som enligt PuL åligger oss beträffande säkerheten vid vår behandling av personuppgifter?
question.answer: IT-policyn innehåller endast våra interna regler om vad som gäller i jobbet och har därför inget med PuL att göra.
IT-policyn kan hjälpa oss att fullgöra vår skyldighet enligt PuL att informera våra medarbetare och ge oss stöd att behandla uppgifter för att se till att vi inte bryter mot PuL.
IT-policyn är ett bra verktyg för att hålla koll på hur vi och våra anställda behandlar personuppgifter, men den är ogiltig om den inte godkänts av facket.

question.text: För att vi ska kunna genomföra effektiva incidentutredningar behöver vi kunna använda den information vi har i våra system. Där kan personuppgifter ingå. Kan vi egentligen ha någon rätt att behandla personuppgifter i våra egna incidentutredningar?
question.answer: NEJ, det är endast de brottsutredande myndigheterna (polisen, åklagarmyndigheten etc) som får behandla personuppgifter i brottsutredningar och därför får vi inte själva utreda om personuppgifter behöver behandlas, utan måste överlåta allt utredningsarbete till polisen.

JA, eftersom uppgifterna finns i våra system och systemen är vår egendom så får vi behandla alla uppgifter som finns där på det sätt vi vill, så länge vi inte därigenom själva begår något brott (förtal, ärekränkning m.m)

JA, men bara begränsat till sådana personuppgifter som behövs för själva utredningen, bara så länge utredningen pågår och för att framställa krav eller anmäla incidenten, samtidigt som bara den personal som utför utredningen får ha tillgång till uppgifterna och uppgifterna måste tas bort när utredningen är avslutad.

question.text: Which type of access control is considered to be user-directed?
question.answer: Nondiscretionary
Mandatory
Identity-based
Discretionary

question.text: Which of the following firewalls acts as a middleman?
question.answer: Packet filtering
Stateful Inspection
Proxy
Dynamic Packet Filtering
Execute code and monitor interactions with the OS.
Analyze code and structure of the code
Compares virus signature to its database signatures
Attaches code to the file to "look" infected

question.text: Which of the following types of malware can replicate?
question.answer: Trojan horse
Bacteria
Zombie
Logic bomb

question.text: I SS-ISO/IEC 27002 används begreppet Informationssäkerhetspolicy. Vad avser vi i Sverige att en policy bör vara?
question.answer: Ett uttryck för ledningens vilja hur verksamheten ska förhålla sig i en viss sak/ämne.
Ett uttryck för hur vi gör saker och ting i en verksamhet, alltifrån hur vi hanterar miljö till hur vi tar backup, dvs omfattar allt vi gör inom ramen för verksamheten.
En policy är en tydlig och omfattande reglering för vad vi gör inom verksamheten och vad påföljden blir om någon gör fel.
En policy ska vara så tydlig att den aktivt styr varje anställds handlande i givna situationer.
En policy ska vara så kortfattad och så tydligt skriven att alla kan förstå den.

question.text: Vilken är definitionen av informationssäkerhet enligt SS-ISO/IEC 27002?
question.answer: Informationssäkerhet är ett riskbaserat skydd av en organisations IT- och informationssystem avseende att rätt information kommer till rätt person vid rätt tidpunkt.
Informationssäkerhet är reglerna för hur information skall hanteras på ett säkert sätt i organisationen.
Informationssäkerhet är ledningens acceptans av nivå på skydd så att informationen skyddas enligt verksamhetens behov.
Att samtliga informationstillgångar har en klassning som gör det möjligt att applicera rätt skyddsnivå, och standarden ger en guide hur detta kan åstadkommas, dvs inforamtionssäkerhet.
Informationens skydd enligt de s k CIA-begreppen (konfidentialitet, riktighet och tillgänglighet) kompletterat med t ex spårbarhet och autenticitet.

question.text: Utöver funktionerna 'kravställande roll' och 'ansvarig för att skydd finns' beskriver SS-ISO/IEC 27002 en tredje viktig roll i LIS arbetet, vilken beskrivning är korrekt?
question.answer: Det skall finnas en koordinerande roll som samlar alla centrala frågor och kan stödja informationssäkerhetsarbetet.
Det skall finnas en informationssäkerhetschef som har rollen som innebär allt ansvar för informationssäkerheten i organisationen.
Det är ledningen själv som har den tredje rollen genom att de är ytterst ansvariga för allt.
Externa konsulter som skall vara experter som man skall anlita vid behov.
En tydlig audit/revisionsfunktion som ansvarar för att de granskningar som görs hålls opåverkade av interna roller och ansvar.

question.text: Vilken svensk grundlag är det som också påverkar informationssäkerheten?
question.answer: Lagar som anger spårbarhet av ekonomisk bokföring i minst 10 år.
Lagar kring hur offentlig upphandlning får ske.
Lagar kring personuppgifter som alltid gäller om man hanterar personuppgifter.
Lagar kring myndigheters föreskrivningsrätt vilket i sin tur resulterat i MBS:s föreskrift om SS-ISO/IEC 27001 och 27002 (MSBFS 2009:10).
Lagar kring yttrande och tryckfrihet som gäller.

question.text: Mot vilken informationssäkerhetsstandard kan jag certifiera mitt företag?
question.answer: SS-ISO/IEC 27001:2014
BS-ISO/EWS 27008:1199
Både ISO/IEC 27002:2005 och SS-ISO/IEC 27001:2014
BITS KBM 2003:2

question.text: Ledningen av ett revisionsprogram kännetecknas för sin roll att:
question.answer: Styra med vilket periodicitet revisioner planeras.
Styra omfattningen av revision, d v s vilken del av organisationen och vilket område som skall revideras.
Metodiskt styra uppbyggnad av revision med olika faser som påminner om PDCA.
Det är oberoende av förklaringen och den ansats som revisionen avger innan revisionen samt dess styrning.
Det är certifieringsordningen som styr revisionen inför en certifiering.

question.text: Vad står CRL för i PKI-sammanhang?
question.answer: Certificate Role Legality
Control and Revocation Logg
Certificate Revocation List
Central Register Logg
Certificate Registration List

question.text: Vad syftar monitorering i ISO/IEC 27001 till?
question.answer: Att skapa ett incidenthanteringssystem.
Att detektering sker av brister så att åtgärder kan vidtas fortlöpande.
Att vi vet vem som skall göra vad.
Att vi har kontroll på hur väl våra informationsresurser utnyttjas så att vi kan maximera servicegraden.
Att uppfylla externa krav på monitorering.
Ledningsfunktioner
Händelser som hanteras inom normal drift
Externa parters åtaganden/leveranser
Allt som berör risker omfattas så frågan är inte relevant
Resurser som inte är IT-relaterade

question.text: Vad kallas ett angrepp som är riktat mot en specifik måltavla och där angriparen arbetar mer långsiktigt samt investerar mer tid och resurser?
question.answer: PST (Permanent System Threat)
APT (Advanced Persistent Threat)
ATT (Advanced Threat Target)
PSA (Permanent System Attack)
HIB (Hack in the Box)

question.text: En individ som navigerar till en webbsida och som ofrivilligt laddar ned en trojan har råkat ut för..
question.answer: Botnet
Involuntary System Threat
Ransomware
Drive By Download
Phising
Cyberterrorism
Dagen som en hacker börjar sina angrepp
En attack där angriparen lyckas komma in på första försöket
En sårbarhet som är okänd för leverantören och som det inte släppts en uppdatering till
Ett välkänt verktyg för att attackera webbplatser

question.text: Vilket av följande alternativ är inte med i OWASP Top 10?
question.answer: Injection
Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF)
Port Scan
Broken Authentication and Session Management
Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)

question.text: Varför är det nödvändigt att hålla en katastrofplan uppdaterad och testa den regelbundet?
question.answer: För att alltid ha tillgång till de senaste säkerhetskopiorna som finns utanför kontoret.
För att kunna klara av daglig förekommande fel.
För annars, i händelse av långtgående/ingripande störningar kan de åtgärder som vidtagits samt planerade procedurer för händelsen, vara olämpliga eller föråldrade.
Eftersom detta krävs av personuppgiftslagen.

question.text: Vilken av följande är den viktigaste faktorn som påverkar en medarbetares beteende i en organisation?
question.answer: Organisationens administrativa regelverk.
Organisationens tekniska system och skydd.
Medarbetarens egen bakgrund och privata förhållanden.
Kollegors och chefers beteenden som speglar vilket beteende medarbetaren får.
Medarbetarens kunskap och förståelse.

question.text: Vem är personuppgiftsansvarig enligt personuppgiftslagen (PuL) om kunden behandlar personuppgifterna genom anlitande av molntjänstleverantör?
question.answer: Molntjänstleverantören, eftersom denne i sin tur fritt bestämmer vilken underleverantör (underbiträde) som anlitas.
Kunden, eftersom personuppgifterna inte kan överföras i ett avtal med molntjänstleverantören.
Underleverantören (underbiträdet), eftersom det inte kan krävas av kunden eller molntjänstleverantören att de ska kunna ha koll på vad som gäller i underleverantörens (underbiträdets) land.

question.text: Är vi skyldiga att aktivt hjälpa polisen om de kommer till vårt företag/myndighet för att göra en husrannsakan och ta föremål eller skriftliga handlingar i beslag?
question.answer: NEJ - vi är inte skyldiga att hjälpa polisen, men vi kan välja att göra det om det är lämpligt.
JA - polisen har alltid rätt att begära att allmänheten bistår polisen när de verkställer olika tvångsmedel.
JA - men bara om det är fråga om ett grövre brott är allmänheten skyldig att hjälpa polisen.

question.text: Hur kan en IT-policy juridiskt ha betydelse för företagets/myndighetens interna incidentutredning?
question.answer: IT-policyn är ur juridisk aspekt betydelselös, eftersom de anställda är skyldiga att hålla sig informerade om vad som gäller.
IT-policyn är viktig ur juridisk aspekt, eftersom det kan avgöra ansvarsfrågan om den anställde har informerats om vad som gäller.
IT-policyn är ur juridisk aspekt betydelselös, eftersom dess enda betydelse är att informera de anställda hur IT-verktygen får användas.

question.text: Finns det några konkreta krav på olika säkerhetsåtgärder i lagstiftningen?
question.answer: NEJ, det finns överhuvudtaget inga säkerhetskrav i lagstiftningen. Därmed lämnas det öppet för företag och myndigheter att själva bestämma säkerhetskraven.
JA, lagstiftningen innehåller tydliga krav och beskrivningar om vilka åtgärder som måste vidtas, både på funktionell nivå och rent tekniskt.

JA, det finns säkerhetskrav i lagstiftningen. Dessa är dock beskrivna med termer som "lämpligt", "nödvändigt" och liknande. De behöver därför kompletteras med tillämpningsföreskrifter m.m från tillsynsmyndigheter och branschorganisationer.
ISO/IEC 27001
ISO/IEC 27035
ISO/IEC 22301
ISO/IEC 27002
ISO/IEC 27005

question.text: Vilken är den sista av de sex huvudfaserna i IT-incidentrapportering enligt SANS?
question.answer: Radering
Återställning
Lärdomar
Bevissäkring
Inneslutning

question.text: Är vi skyldiga att kontrollera att den person som representerar min motpart i ett avtal, verkligen är den hen påstår eller är behörig företrädare för motparten?
question.answer: NEJ - Det är alltid motparten som får stå för konsekvenserna av att någon obehörigigen agerar i dennes namn, varför vi inte är skyldiga att kontrollera om så är fallet.
NEJ - Någon skyldighet att kontrollera finns inte, men vi riskerar att inte kunna göra avtalet gällande mot motparten om vi väljer att endast lite på vad företrädaren påstår.
JA - Om vi inte fortlöpande kontrollerar den påstådde företrädaren med motparten blir vi skyldiga att ersätta denne all skada som denne kan drabbas av p.g.a. den obehörige företrädaren.

question.text: Vad utmärker kontinuitetsplanering sett ur ett informationssäkerhetsperspektiv?
question.answer: Att det handlar om avbrottsfri leverans av IT-tjänster oavsett vad som inträffar.
Att de informationsrelaterade risker som man bedömmer ha stor inverkan ska beaktas även om de händer sällan.
Kontinuitetsplanering beaktar risker som berör hela verksamheten så därför kan man bortse från denna.
Det handlar bara om fysisk säkerhet och hur information skall skyddas utifrån stora händelser som har fysisk påverkan t ex brand.
Det berör varumärket och därför så skall alla risker även med i kontinuitetsplaneringen.

question.text: Vilket alternativ är inte korrekt enligt definitionen av fysisk säkerhet i 27002?
question.answer: Skalskydd
Personskydd
Skydd av hemarbetsplatser
Avveckling
Kablage

question.text: Vad är det som skall styra för hur vi inför LIS enligt PDCA processen?
question.answer: Behovet att kunna påvisa att man följer standarden enligt krav från någon extern part.
Revisioner av verksamhetens informationssäkerhet.
Ledningens genomgång av informationssäkerheten.
Intressenterns förväntningar och krav på informationssäkerheten.
Externa regler och lagar som berör informationssäkerheten.

question.text: Vad skiljer det första PDCA varvet från de återkommande?
question.answer: Säkerhetsorganisationen måste skapas.
Det är inriktat på att införa LIS.
Det är först i andra varvet som man har ledningens genomgång.
Policyn är inte påskriven av ledningen förrän man haft första ledningens genomgång.
Man har ingen informationssäkerhet förrän första varvet är genomgått.

question.text: Vår tillgång till information blir allt mer lättare. Ändå, ska informationen vara tillförlitlig för att bli användbar. Vad är inte en tillförlitlighetsaspekt av information?
question.answer: Tillgänglighet
Integritet
Kvantitet
Sekretess
Backup

question.text: Vad är det huvudsakliga syftet med riskhantering?
question.answer: Att bestämma sannolikheten att en viss risk kommer inträffa.
Att fastställa skadan orsakad av möjliga säkerhetsincidenter.
Att beskriva de hot som IT-resurser är utsatta för.
Att använda åtgärder för att minska riskerna till acceptabel nivå.
Att visa säkerhetschefens betydelse.

question.text: Vilken av dessa händelser är inte en säkerhetsrelaterad incident?
question.answer: En brandvarnare fungerar inte.
Nätverket är hackat.
Någon låtsas vara anställd.
En fil på datorn kan inte konverteras till en PDF-fil.

question.text: Säkerhetsåtgärder kan grupperas på olika sätt. Vilket av följande är mest korrekt?
question.answer: Fysisk, logisk, förebyggande.
Logisk, repressiv, förebyggande.
Organisatorisk, förebyggande, korrigerande, fysisk.
Organisatoriska, fysiska, logiska.
Att avgöra vilken typ av information som kräver olika skyddsnivåer.
Att tilldela uppgifter till en ägare.
Att minska risker för mänskliga fel.
Att förhindra obehörig tillgång/åtkomst till information.

question.text: Fyra anställda vid IT-avdelningen delar på ett passerkort till datorrummet. Vilken risk leder detta till?
question.answer: Om strömmen bryts, datorerna slocknar.
Om brand bryter ut och brandsläckarna inte kan användas.
Om något försvinner från datorrummet kommer det inte stå klart vem som är ansvarig.
Obehöriga personer kan få tillgång till datasalen utan att bli sedda.

question.text: Vilket av följande säkerhetsåtgärder är en teknisk åtgärd?
question.answer: Allokering av informationen till en ägare.
Kryptering av filer.
Skapa en policy som definierar vad som är och inte tillåtet i e-post.
Säker förvaring av system management lösenord.
Internutbildningar.

question.text: Vad är exempel på en organisatorisk åtgärd?
question.answer: Back-up av data.
Kryptering.
Avskiljande/uppdelning av arbetsuppgifter.
Hålla nätverksutrustning och kopplingsdosor i ett låst rum.
Fastställande av en persons identitet.
Registrering av åtgärder som vidtas.
Verifiering av persons identitet.
Beviljandet av särskilda rättigheter, såsom selektiv åtkomst för en person.

question.text: Standarden för informationssäkerhet 27002 gäller bara för stora företag. Är detta påstående korrekt?
question.answer: Ja
Nej
Till viss del. Standarden är menad att användas av stora företag men ingenting hindrar företag att följa standarden.

question.text: Varför väljer revisorn ofta att göra kontroller i form av stickprov vid revision?
question.answer: För att sticka hål på felaktikt beskrivna säkerhetsdokument.
För att slippa granska all användning av en säkerhetsåtgärd i olika delar av verksamheten.
För att verifiera verkan av en enskild säkerhetsåtgärd.
För att undvika problem som uppstår vid implementeringen.

question.text: Vad kallas dokumentet, vilket krävs vid certifieringsrevision, som bland annat beskriver motiv till valet av säkerhetsåtgärd?
question.answer: Uttalande om lämplighet (Statement of suitability)
Uttalande om tillämplighet (Statement of applicability)
Uttalande om policy (Statement of policy)
Uttalande om risk (Statement of risk)

question.text: På vilket sätt bör en revisor bilda sig en uppfattning om ledningssystemets effekt på verksamhetens informationssäkerhet?
question.answer: Genom dokumentgranskning
Intervjuer med medarbetare
Egen verifiering / test
Alla nämnda
Ingen av de nämnda

question.text: Vilken roll har standarden 27002 (lista på säkerhetsåtgärder) vid certifiering mot 27001?
question.answer: Ingen; allt som rör certifieringen hittas i 27001.
Är ett alternativ; man kan välja att certifiera sig mot 27002 istället.
Komplement; 27002 kan användas för att identifiera säkerhetsåtgärder.
Obligatorisk; 27002 ska användas för att identifiera säkerhetsåtgärder.

question.text: Varför är det viktigt med opartiskhet i samband med revision av informationssäkerhet generellt?
question.answer: Det är ett lagkrav i alla EU-länder.
Det är inte bra ifall parterna i revisionen tar ställning för eller emot ledningssystemet.
Genom bland annat opartiskhet säkerställs att inga andra hänsyn tas än de fakta som framkommer vid revisionen.
För att ingen ska kunna ta del av resultatet från revisionen tidigare än någon av de andra parterna.

question.text: När kan det finnas anledning att ha olika nivåer på autentisering inom en organisation?
question.answer: När man vet att vissa grupper av anställda är mer slarviga med att välja lösenord än andra.
När en riskanalys visat att obehörig åtkomst till viss information medför allvarligare konsekvenser än obehörig åtkomst till annan typ av information.
När det finns en ökad risk för vissa användare att någon kikar över axeln och avslöjar en annan användares lösenord.
När påloggning i vissa system sker via iPhone eller liknande.
När organisationen anlitar flera konsulter.

question.text: Incidenthantering består av såväl proaktiva som reaktiva aktiviteter. Vilka av följande aktiviteter räknas inte som en reaktiv aktivitet?
question.answer: Incidentåtgärder
Teknisk analys
Utredning och bevissäkring
Polisanmälan
Extern anmälan

question.text: Vilka är de 6 huvudfaserna i IT-incidenthantering?
question.answer: Samverkan, Granskning, Inneslutning, Motattack, Återställning, Avrapportering.
Upphandlning, Identifiering, Inneslutning, Motattack, Återställning, Avrapportering.
Förberedelser, Samverkan, Inneslutning, Radering, Återställning, Avrapportering.
Förberedelser, Identifiering, Inneslutning, Radering, Återställning, Lärdomar.
Upphandling, Granskning, Inneslutning, Radering, Återställning, Lärdomar.

question.text: Vilket av nedanstående påstående är mest sant?
question.answer: En händelse är en påverkan och en incident är en farlig händelse.
En händelse loggas alltid i säkerhetsloggen och en incident är en skadlig händelse.
En händelse är en påverkan på ett system och en incident är en skadlig händelse.
En händelse får alltid systemet att ändra funktion och en incident är en skadlig händelse.
En händelse är en påverkan som ibland observeras på flera ställen och en incident är en kostsam händelse.

question.text: Which of the following alternatives correctly describes passwords?
question.answer: Least expensive and most secure
Most expensive and least secure
Least expensive and least secure
Most expensive and most secure

answers.answer: An object-oriented middleware technology.
The main Exterior Gateway Protocol used in the Internet, BGP provides routing among Autonomous Systems.
An Ethernet interface that can automatically sense the maximum speed of a connected device and choose to operate at 10 Mbps or 100 Mbps.
The protocol a computer uses to map an IP address into a hardware address. A computer that invokes ARP broadcasts a request to which the target computer re- plies.
Any change introduced as data passes across a network. Transmission errors can be caused by electrical interference or hardware that malfunctions.
The technical name for 10 Mbps twisted pair Ethernet.
A device used to debug network problems or monitor performance. An analyzer captures packets from a network and reports statistics such as the percentage of broadcast traffic.
The IP addressing and routing scheme that replaced classful addressing. CIDR uses a 32-bit address mask to denote the boundary between the prefix and suffix of an IP address.
The technical name for fast Ethernet (100 Mbps).
Synonym for link-status.

A number in a protocol header that determines how many intermediate machines a packet visits. Protocols like IP require the sender to specify a maximum hop count; doing so prevents a packet from traveling around a routing loop forever.
The required header found at the beginning of an IPv6 datagram.
The ability of a transport protocol to change its retransmission timer continuously to accommodate variations in internet delay. TCP is the best known protocol that uses adaptive retransmission.
The technical name for gigabit Ethernet.
A domain name server that knows the locations of top-level domains such as .com and .edu.
A Wide Area Network technology that provides connection-oriented service.

A reference to a cable in which the wire used to transmit on one end connects to the wire used to receive on the other, and vice-versa. The numbers 2 and 3 refer to the transmit and receive pins on a DB-25 connector.
The technical name for fast Ethernet (100 Mbps).
The method of interaction used when two application programs communicate over a network. A server application waits at a known address, and a client application contacts the server.
A mathematical result from information theory that specifies an upper bound on the maximum rate at which data can be sent.
Characteristic of a network technology that connects multiple computers but does not support broadcast. ATM is an example of an NBMA network.
An ISDN service that includes two standard telephone connections plus a data connection.
A popular application in which a user or computer sends a memo to one or more recipients.
The automated system used to translate computer names into equivalent IP addresses. A DNS server responds to a query by looking up the name and returning the address.
A UNIX program that performs multicast routing. Mrouted implements the DVMRP protocol, and is used in the MBONE.
A technique used by TCP and other transport protocols to reliably start or. gracefully terminate communication.
A networking technology that uses RF communication to interconnect computers over a short distance.
A multicast routing protocol designed to be used across a set of networks that have many listeners (e.g., across Local Area Networks within an organization).
A small, fixed size packet (e.g., ATM networks send 48-octet cells).

A wiring scheme often used with asynchronous serial connections between a pair of computers. The first wire is used to transmit data from one computer to another, the second wire is used to transmit data in the reverse direction, and the third wire is a common electrical ground.
A server that handles each request independently. Most servers are designed to be as stateless as possible.

A document stored on a World Wide Web server that is the starting point for obtaining information about a particular individual, company, group, or topic. A homepage can contain pointers to. additional pages of related information or to homepages for other topics.

A wiring scheme often used with asynchronous serial connections between a pair of computers. One pair of wires is used to carry data in one direction and the other pair is used to carry data in the reverse direction. A 4-wire circuit is usually used to span longer distances than a 3-wire circuit.
An ISDN service that has sufficient bandwidth for larger businesses.

The designations that telephone companies use for the speeds of popular point-to- point digital circuits. DS-0 denotes a digital voice circuit of 64 Kbps; DS-1 denotes 1.544 Mbps; and DS-3 denotes 44.736 Mbps.

A technique protocols use for dynamic address configuration. A computer selects an address at random, and broadcasts a message to determine whether the address is in use. Alternative schemes use servers to manage addresses.
An important result that specifies the maximum data rate that can be achieved over a transmission channel that has noise associated with it.
A conceptual model that explains how TCP/IP Internet protocols are designed.
A multicast routing protocol designed to be used in cases where only a few networks contain listeners (e.g., across Wide Area Networks in the Internet).
A multicast routing protocol designed to be used across a set of networks that have many listeners (e.g., across Local Area Networks within an organization).

Characteristic of a mechanism used to share a communication medium among multiple senders in which each sender is assigned a unique frequency or channel. Because they use separate frequencies, the simultaneous transmissions do not interfere with one another.
A term used to describe the general shape of a network. Common topologies include bus, point-to-point, ring, and star.
A small, fixed size packet (e.g., ATM networks send 48-octet cells).

An early conceptual model devised by the International Organization for Standardization to specify how a set of protocols work together to provide communication services. The 7-layer model did not include an internet protocol layer.
The system of route servers that each contain complete information about all destinations in the global Internet.
A mathematical result from information theory that specifies an upper bound on the maximum rate at which data can be sent.
The IEEE standard for Logical Link Control, Ethernet, Token Ring and Wi-Fi wireless network.
The method of interaction used when two application programs communicate over a network. A server application waits at a known address, and a client application contacts the server.
A physical wire between two points over which data is sent one bit at a time. RS- 232-C is often used with serial lines.
An IEEE standard for a security mechanism used with wireless networks.
A height for communication satellites in which one orbit takes approximately 90 minutes.
A standard that assigns unique values to 256 characters, including upper and lower case letters, digits, punctuation, and control characters.
The original privacy mechanism that was part of IEEE 802.11 wireless networks. WEP was found to be insufficient.
Microsoft's name for their Web server product.

A small value a Web server passes to a browser in a reply to help the server identify the user. A browser returns the cookie when sending subsequent requests from the user to the server that issued the cookie.
The protocol an application uses to send data over an ATM network. AAL5, which is part of the ATM stack, accepts and delivers large packets of data (up to 64K bytes).
A type of service offered by ATM.
A range of frequencies used for sending radio signals through the air (e.g., from a commercial radio station). Wireless network technologies use RF.
Any time-division multiplexing mechanism that proceeds round-robin among all sources. The acronym is also expanded to Slotted Time Division Multiplexing.

The address assigned to a computer that attaches to a network. A frame sent from one computer to another must contain the recipient's hardware address. A hardware address is also called a physical address or a MAC address.
An algorithm that bridges use when they boot to detect and break cycles.
The hypermedia system used on the Internet in which a page of information can contain text, images, audio, video clips, and references to other pages.
The time a network interface waits before it can access a shared network.
Term applied to any route propagation protocol used to transfer routing information within a single Autonomous Systems.
A security mechanism that specifies users or computer programs that can access a particular object.
A mechanism used to build clients and servers. RPC inserts code in a program to allow a procedure call to extend across a network.
A parity bit added to a unit of data, usually each character, to make the number of 1 bits even. A receiver checks the parity to determine whether data has been corrupted during transmission.
A form of addressing used by IPv6 in which a set of computers is assigned one address; a datagram sent to the address can be delivered to any one of the computers in the set.

A connection from one computer to another through a connection-oriented network. The term virtual arises because the circuit is achieved by placing routes in routing tables, not by establishing physical wires. Also called a virtual channel.
A high-speed multiplexing technology used with optical fiber.
A device that accepts a modulated carrier wave and extracts the information used to modulate it.
A short message returned to inform a sender that data has arrived at its intended destination.

A World Wide Web document that is a computer program. After downloading an active document, the browser runs the program on the user's computer. The active document can change the display continuously.
A set of packets transmitted back to back. Packet traffic tends to be bursty.
A form of NAT proposed by cable TV companies.
A height for communication satellites in which one orbit takes approximately 90 minutes.
The ability of a transport protocol to change its retransmission timer continuously to accommodate variations in internet delay. TCP is the best known protocol that uses adaptive retransmission.
A form of NAT proposed by cable TV companies.
A parity bit added to a unit of data, usually each character, to make the number of 1 bits odd. A receiver checks the parity to determine whether data has been corrupted during transmission;
A Wide Area Network technology that provides connection-oriented service.

An error that occurs on asynchronous serial lines in which the receiver does not detect a valid frame (usually a character). Differences in the sender's and receiver's baud rate can cause framing errors.
A unique binary value assigned to a computer; network hardware and software uses the address in a packet to forward the packet to its destination.
A set of named items that an SNMP agent understands. To monitor or control a remote computer, a manager must fetch or store values to MIB variables.

A connection from one computer to another through a connection-oriented network. The term virtual arises because the circuit is achieved by placing routes in routing tables, not by establishing physical wires. Also called a virtual channel.
A 32-bit value that specifies how an IP address is divided into network and host portions. Address bits not covered by the mask correspond to the host portion. Also called a subnet mask.
The number of changes in a signal per second. Each change can encode one or more bits of information.
A protocol developed by the IETF that provides signaling for IP telephony systems.
The name of a Linux program that implements Network Address Translation.
The TCP/IP protocol that provides application programs with connectionless communication service.
The mapping from one address to another, usually from a high-level address (e.g., an IP address) to a low-level address (e.g., an Ethernet address).

A network that uses technology designed to span a small geographic area. For example, an Ethernet is a LAN technology suitable for use in a single building. LANs have lower propagation delay than WANs or MANs.
A subtree of the computer naming hierarchy used in the Internet. For example, commercial organizations have names registered under the .com domain.

The total amount of time a packet must wait in packet switches as it travels through a. packet switching network. The queueing delay is related to the amount of traffic in a network— when no other packets are being sent, the queueing delay is zero.

A technology to deliver digital information at high-speed over the same twisted pair wiring used to deliver telephone service. The downstream bit rate is higher than the upstream rate because most subscribers retrieve much more information than they send.
A broadcast to all computers on a remote network achieved by sending a single copy of the packet to the remote network and broadcasting the packet when it arrives. TCP/IP supports directed broadcast.
A protocol developed by the IETF that provides signaling for IP telephony systems.
A modem that can send and receive information by modulating a radio frequency carrier. RF modems are used in wireless network technologies.
Access to an FTP server using the login name anonymous and the password guest. Not all FTP servers permit anonymous FTP.

A device attached to the end of a wire or a transmission cable to prevent electrical signals from reflecting back. A bus network such as an Ethernet requires each end of the cable to have a terminator.

The protocol that specifies how a network management station communicates with agent software in remote devices such as routers; the current version is number 3. SNMP defines the format of messages and their meaning.
A scheme for digital encoding of audio in which successive values represent differences in the sampled wave instead of absolute values.
A unit of data transfer equal to 1000 Mbps or 109 bps.
The protocol that IP uses to report errors and exceptions. ICMP also includes informational messages used by programs like ping.
A device that accepts a modulated carrier wave and extracts the information used to modulate it.

A generic reference to a set of procedures that an application" program uses to access a service. A network API consists of procedures a program uses to access protocol software; the most well-known is the socket API.
A markup language used for Web pages that contain audio (typically used with cell phones).
The protocol that IP uses to report errors and exceptions. ICMP also includes informational messages used by programs like ping.
A set of packets headed for the same destination.
The technique used with bus architecture networks in which computers attached to the common bus check for the presence of a carrier before transmitting.
A computer program that forms the central part of an active World Wide Web document. An applet is written in a programming language such as Java.
A standard format for digital video and audio that allows the two streams to be synchronized (i.e., played together). The name is derived from the committee that published the standard.

A document stored on a World Wide Web server that is the starting point for obtaining information about a particular individual, company, group, or topic. A homepage can contain pointers to. additional pages of related information or to homepages for other topics.

A condition in which,.each packet sent through a network experiences excessive delay because the network is overrun with packets. Unless protocol software detects congestion and reduces the rate at which packets are sent, a network can experience congestion collapse.
Characteristic of the current IP addressing scheme in which a 32-bit address mask is used to determine the division between the prefix and suffix of an IP address.
A wireless networking technology used for short distances (e.g., to connect a wireless mouse to a computer).
An old set of network protocols developed and sold by Apple Computer Corporation.

An early conceptual model devised by the International Organization for Standardization to specify how a set of protocols work together to provide communication services. The 7-layer model did not include an internet protocol layer.

A program that acts as a proxy to provide service indirectly. Application gateways are used in Internet firewalls to allow employees in an organization to access the Internet according to the organization's security policy.
The global Internet that uses TCP/IP protocols.
A measure of the capacity of a transmission system. Bandwidth is measured in Hertz.
An OSPF term for a set of routers that use OSPF to exchange link-status information.

A form of packet delivery in which each computer is assigned a unique address. When a packet is sent to a unicast address, exactly one copy of the packet is delivered to the computer to which the address corresponds. Unicast delivery is the most common type.
The protocol used to transfer e-mail from one computer to another across the Internet. SMTP is part of the TCP/IP protocol suite.

A popular Local Area Network technology that uses a shared bus topology and CSMA/CD access. Basic Ethernet operates at 10 Mbps, Fast Ethernet operates at 100 Mbps, and Gigabit Ethernet operates at 1000 Mbps (i.e., 1 Gbps).
The protocol a computer uses to map an IP address into a hardware address. A computer that invokes ARP broadcasts a request to which the target computer re- plies.
A multicast routing protocol designed to be used in cases where only a few networks contain listeners (e.g., across Wide Area Networks in the Internet).

Characteristic of a mechanism used to share a communication medium among multiple senders in which each sender is assigned a unique frequency or channel. Because they use separate frequencies, the simultaneous transmissions do not interfere with one another.
A multicast routing protocol that extends OSPF to handle multicast.

An error that occurs on asynchronous serial lines in which the receiver does not detect a valid frame (usually a character). Differences in the sender's and receiver's baud rate can cause framing errors.
A connectionless Wide Area Network technology offered by telephone companies.
A term used to describe the general shape of a network. Common topologies include bus, point-to-point, ring, and star.
A group of networks and routers under one administrative authority. For routing purposes, the Internet is divided into Autonomous Systems.

question.text: ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange)

answers.answer: Term applied to any route propagation protocol used to transfer routing information within a single Autonomous Systems.

An electronic device that connects a leased digital data circuit to computer equipment. The DSU/CSU translates between the digital format used by the telephone companies and the format used by the computer industry.
A standard that assigns unique values to 128 characters, including upper and lower case letters, digits, punctuation, and control characters. Details can be found in Appendix 2.
A set of named items that an SNMP agent understands. To monitor or control a remote computer, a manager must fetch or store values to MIB variables.
A network architecture in which all computers attach to a shared medium, often a single cable. The bus architecture is mainly used for Local Area Networks.
A standard for representing data. The SNMP protocol uses ASN.l to represent object names.

A general term used to describe the operation of a switch. Because it is associated with hardware, switching is usually higher speed than routing. Also, switching differs from routing because switching uses the hardware address in a frame.
An encryption technology popular among computer scientists.
The former name of the ITU.
A dynamic Web page technology closely linked to Microsoft's Web server. The server interprets Visual Basic code that is embedded in each page whenever the page is requested.

The protocol a host uses to inform a router when it joins (or leaves) an Internet multicast group. IGMP is only used on a local network; a router must use another multicast routing protocol to inform other routers of group membership.

A cable that contains one (or more) twisted pairs of wire surrounded by a heavy metal shield similar to the shield that surrounds a single wire in a coaxial cable. The shield protects the inner pairs of wires from electrical interference.

An address in a packet that specifies the computer that sent the packet. In a hardware frame, the source address must be a hardware address. In an IP datagram, the source address must be an IP address.
A value found in the header of an IP datagram. Each router decrements the TTL value. If the TTL reaches zero, the router discards the datagram and sends an ICMP error message to the source.
A height for communication satellites in which one orbit takes approximately 90 minutes.
Characteristic of any communication system in which the sender can transmit data without warning. The receiver must be prepared to accept data at any time.
A set of named items that an SNMP agent understands. To monitor or control a remote computer, a manager must fetch or store values to MIB variables.
"A system used for call setup between an IP telephone system and the PSTN.
A- connection-oriented technology defined by the ITU and the ATM Forum. At the lowest level, ATM sends data in fixed cells with 48 octets of data per cell.

An experimental system used to send multicast data across the Internet. Although MBONE routers multicast locally, they use an IP tunnel to transfer multicast datagrams across the Internet from one site to another.
The hypermedia system used on the Internet in which a page of information can contain text, images, audio, video clips, and references to other pages.
A protocol developed by the IETF that provides signaling for IP telephony systems.
The type of connector used with the original, thick wire Ethernet.
Wiring in which pairs of wires are twisted together to minimize interference, but no other shielding is provided.
A step that a computer system must perform to assign values to parameters before protocol software can be used. Usually, protocol configuration requires a system to obtain a protocol address.
A standard for digital encoding used by the telephone companies.
A technique used to prevent broadcast packets from traversing a topological loop.
The mechanism that a 10/100 Ethernet port uses to detect the maximum speed of a computer.
A synonym for thin wire Ethernet.

A library of graphics procedures used with the Java language to manipulate windows on a bit-mapped display. At various times, the designers have expanded AWT to Alternative Window Toolkit and Applet Widget Toolkit.

A general concept that refers to separating information received over a common communication channel into its original components. Demultiplexing occurs both in hardware (i.e., electrical signals can be demultiplexed) and in software (i.e., protocol software can demultiplex incoming messages and pass each to the correct application program).
A unit of data transfer equal to 1000 bits per second.

When two programs communicate over a network, a client is the one that initiates communication, while a server is the program that waits to be contacted. A given program can act as a server for one service and a client for another.

A program that acts as a proxy to provide service indirectly. Application gateways are used in Internet firewalls to allow employees in an organization to access the Internet according to the organization's security policy.
The term telephone companies use to denote a channel configured to handle a voice telephone circuit. ISDN includes B channel service.
A mathematical result from information theory that specifies an upper bound on the maximum rate at which data can be sent.
A measure of the capacity of a transmission system. Bandwidth is measured in Hertz.
A synonym for hop count that is used by IPv6.

A network architecture in which a computer has a point-to-point connection to other computer(s). Full mesh networks, in which each pair of computers is directly connected, offer the highest throughput but are uncommon because they are expensive and difficult to change.

The total amount of time a packet must wait in packet switches as it travels through a. packet switching network. The queueing delay is related to the amount of traffic in a network— when no other packets are being sent, the queueing delay is zero.
A binary value used in an ATM network to identify a particular connection. Each switch along a path rewrites the VPI/VCI.
Characteristic of a network in which each transmission is independent. The alternative to connectionless networking is connection-oriented networking.
The required header found at the beginning of an IPv6 datagram.

Characteristic of the original IP addressing scheme in which unicast addresses were divided into three primary classes. The class of an address determines the division between the prefix and suffix in the address.

The term used to describe a networking technology that uses a small part of the electromagnetic spectrum and sends only one signal at a time over the underlying medium. Most LANs use baseband signaling (e.g., Ethernet and FDDI).

A connection from one computer to another through a connection-oriented network. The term virtual arises because the circuit is achieved by placing routes in routing tables, not by establishing physical wires. Also called a virtual channel.
An alternative to packet switching in which the network hardware forms a circuit between two communicating endpoints. The original telephone network used circuit switching.
A term used to describe the general shape of a network. Common topologies include bus, point-to-point, ring, and star.
A parity bit added to a unit of data, usually each character, to make the number of 1 bits odd. A receiver checks the parity to determine whether data has been corrupted during transmission;
A unit of measure equal to an oscillation per second. Hardware bandwidth is measured in multiples of Hertz.
The number of changes in a signal per second. Each change can encode one or more bits of information.
Abbreviation for optical fiber.
A protocol that a computer system uses during bootstrap to obtain an IP address.

A wiring scheme often used with asynchronous serial connections between a pair of computers. The first wire is used to transmit data from one computer to another, the second wire is used to transmit data in the reverse direction, and the third wire is a common electrical ground.
A physical wire between two points over which data is sent one bit at a time. RS- 232-C is often used with serial lines.
Characteristic of any network system that makes a best attempt to deliver data, but does hot guarantee delivery. Many networks use the best-effort approach.
A measure of the capacity of a transmission system. Bandwidth is measured in Hertz.
A cookie that a browser holds in memory. Because it is kept in memory instead of on disk, a session cookie only persists while the browser is running.
The main Exterior Gateway Protocol used in the Internet, BGP provides routing among Autonomous Systems.

A program used to forward e-mail messages. A mail exploder consults a database to determine how to handle each message. The name arises because a mail exploder may send copies of a message to multiple recipients if the database specifies many recipients for a given address.
A special address that causes the underlying system to deliver a copy of a packet to all computers on a network.
A dynamic Web page technology intended to be platform-independent. Whenever the page is requested, the server interprets Java code that is embedded in each page.
A synonym for thick wire Ethernet.

A technique protocols use for dynamic address configuration. A computer selects an address at random, and broadcasts a message to determine whether the address is in use. Alternative schemes use servers to manage addresses.
The scheme used by computers on an Ethernet following a collision. Each computer doubles the time it waits after each successive collision.
The process of changing a carrier wave (usually a sine wave) to encode information. The frequency of the carrier and the modulation technique determine the rate at which data can be sent.
A UNIX program that performs multicast routing. Mrouted implements the DVMRP protocol, and is used in the MBONE.
The organization that controls standards for telephone systems. The ITU also standardizes a few network technologies (e.g., ATM).
The former name of the ITU.
The form of a packet sent across a TCP/IP internet. Each datagram contains two pieces: a header that identifies both the sender and receiver and a payload area that contains the data being carried.

A technique protocols use for dynamic address configuration. A computer selects an address at random, and broadcasts a message to determine whether the address is in use. Alternative schemes use servers to manage addresses.
The name of a popular program that implements Domain Name Server functionality.
A wireless networking technology used for short distances (e.g., to connect a wireless mouse to a computer).

A network architecture in which computers are linked into a cycle with the first connected to the second, the second connected to the third, and so on until the last connects back to the first. Ring topology is usually used in Local Area Networks.
A measure of a network that specifies the amount of data that is present in the network between the sender and receiver.
The protocol that defines both the format of packets used on a TCP/IP Internet and the mechanism for routing a packet to its destination.
The type of connector used with thin wire Ethernet.
The physical layer encoding that Ethernet uses to transmit a frame.
The technical name for gigabit Ethernet.

The protocol that specifies how a network management station communicates with agent software in remote devices such as routers; the current version is number 3. SNMP defines the format of messages and their meaning.
The physical layer encoding that Ethernet uses to transmit a frame.

A transmission technique used to avoid interference and achieve higher throughput. Instead of a single carrier frequency, a sender and receiver agree to use a set of frequencies, either at the same time or by changing from one to another. The technique is especially important for wireless networks.

The amount of electrical energy lost as a wave travels down a medium such as a copper wire. A network connection cannot be arbitrarily long because the signal loss eventually makes the wave too weak to detect.

A protocol that a computer uses when it first starts to obtain information needed to configure the protocol software. BOOTP uses IP and UDP to broadcast a request and receive a response before IP has been completely configured.
The rate at which data can be transmitted across a network. The number of bits per second may differ from the baud rate because more than one bit can be encoded in a single baud.
A measure of a network that specifies the amount of data that is present in the network between the sender and receiver.
The standard for signaling (i.e., call setup and termination) used in the PSTN.
A term used informally to refer to a router or a computer attached to a network. The term is derived from graph theory.

An early conceptual model devised by the International Organization for Standardization to specify how a set of protocols work together to provide communication services. The 7-layer model did not include an internet protocol layer.
The ISDN service that provides two B channels plus a data channel. BRI is suitable for small businesses.
Characteristic of a mechanism that allows multiple senders to share a communication medium by taking turns. At any time, only one sender transmits across the channel.
A synonym for fiber modem.
A security mechanism that watches packets arriving at a site and detects attacks.
A commercial organization that provides its subscribers with access to the Internet.
A set of standards developed by telephone companies for high-speed digital circuits.

A hardware device that connects two LAN segments and copies frames from one to the other. Most bridge hardware uses physical addresses to learn which computers attach to which segments so the bridge can avoid copying frames unless needed.
A modem that uses the dialup telephone network to communicate. Dialup modems use an audible tone as a carrier wave, and must be able to dial or answer a telephone call.

The term used to describe a networking technology that uses a large part of the electromagnetic spectrum to achieve higher throughput rates. Usually broadband systems employ frequency division multiplexing to allow multiple, independent communications to proceed simultaneously over a single underlying medium.

A value used to verify that data is not corrupted during transmission. The sender computes a CRC and transmits the result in a packet with the data. A receiver computes the CRC over the data received, and compares the value to the CRC in the packet. A CRC is more complex to compute than a checksum, but can detect more transmission errors.
A 32-bit value that specifies how an IP address is divided into network and host portions. Address bits not covered by the mask correspond to the host portion. Also called a subnet mask.
A form of delivery in which one copy of a packet is delivered to each computer on a network.
A cookie that a browser holds in memory. Because it is kept in memory instead of on disk, a session cookie only persists while the browser is running.

Characteristic of a network that uses packet switches to forward packets. The name arises because each switch along a path to the destination receives a packet and temporarily stores the packet in. memory. Meanwhile the switch continuously selects a packet from the queue in memory, routes the packet, and then transmits the packet to the appropriate next hop.
A technology used to create dynamic World Wide Web documents. CGI programs run on the server computer.
A security mechanism that specifies users or computer programs that can access a particular object.
A wild-card entry in a routing table. The routing software follows the default route if the table does not contain an explicit route to the destination.
The area of a packet that contains information about the sender, destination, and contents.
A special address that causes the underlying system to deliver a copy of a packet to all computers on a network.
A network system in which a satellite broadcasts all packets and allows individual receivers to discard packets intended for other recipients.
A directory service used with middleware.
A message used for testing and debugging. The ping program sends ICMP echo request messages to elicit echo replies.
A small IP datagram produced by fragmentation.
A subtree of the computer naming hierarchy used in the Internet. For example, commercial organizations have names registered under the .com domain.
A standard that assigns unique values to 256 characters, including upper and lower case letters, digits, punctuation, and control characters.
A term used for IP telephony. VoIP includes call setup and termination as well as the transmission of digitized audio.

A computer program that accesses and displays information from the World Wide Web. A browser contains multiple application programs, and uses an object's name to determine which application should be used to access the object.

A popular Local Area Network technology that uses a shared bus topology and CSMA/CD access. Basic Ethernet operates at 10 Mbps, Fast Ethernet operates at 100 Mbps, and Gigabit Ethernet operates at 1000 Mbps (i.e., 1 Gbps).
A mechanism in a router used to control traffic, typically as part of an Internet firewall. The packet filter discards ail packets that do not adhere to the criteria the manager specifies.
A set of packets transmitted back to back. Packet traffic tends to be bursty.
A network architecture in which all computers attach to a shared medium, often a single cable. The bus architecture is mainly used for Local Area Networks.

A connection from one computer to another through a connection-oriented network. The term virtual arises because the circuit is achieved by placing routes in routing tables, not by establishing physical wires. Also called a virtual channel.
The protocol suite used in the Internet. Although the suite contains many protocols, TCP and IP are two of the most important.
A network architecture in which all computers attach to a shared medium, often a single cable. The bus architecture is mainly used for Local Area Networks.
A network architecture that consists of a central hub to which all computers connect. Star topologies are often used with Local Area Networks (e.g., twisted pair Ethernet).
The procedure a receiver uses to recreate a copy of an original datagram from the fragments that arrive.

A program used to forward e-mail messages. A mail exploder consults a database to determine how to handle each message. The name arises because a mail exploder may send copies of a message to multiple recipients if the database specifies many recipients for a given address.

The protocol a host uses to inform a router when it joins (or leaves) an Internet multicast group. IGMP is only used on a local network; a router must use another multicast routing protocol to inform other routers of group membership.
A protocol technique in which data is changed by inserting additional bytes to distinguish between data values and packet control values (i.e. headers).
A telephone company term for equipment such as a computer that connects to a network.
A standard for representing data. The SNMP protocol uses ASN.l to represent object names.
A modem used to send digital information over the coaxial cables used for cable television,

Characteristic of a mechanism used to share a communication medium among multiple senders in which each sender is assigned a unique frequency or channel. Because they use separate frequencies, the simultaneous transmissions do not interfere with one another.
A technology developed by the telephone companies to provide high speed digital service over local loop wiring.
The basic signal transmitted across a network. A carrier is modulated (i.e., changed) to encode data.
The path of data from the Internet to a residential customer. The term is often used with DSL or cable modem technologies.
A conceptual model that explains how TCP/IP Internet protocols are designed.
A form of addressing used by IPv6 in which a set of computers is assigned one address; a datagram sent to the address can be delivered to any one of the computers in the set.
A form of NAT proposed by cable TV companies.
The time required to send a signal across a network. The term comes from electrical engineering terminology, and describes an electrical signal propagating down a wire.
The technical name of the standard used for serial data connections such as those between a keyboard and a computer. The standard defines such details as the voltage used to represent a 1 and a 0.

A network diagnostic program that finds the address of all routers between the user's computer and a specified destination. Traceroute sends datagrams with successively larger time-to-live values, and uses ICMP error messages to determine routers along the path.
A mechanism that allows nontext data to be sent in a standard Internet e-mail message. A MIME sender encodes data using printable characters; a MIME reader decodes the message.
A type of wiring needed for twisted pair Ethernet. The. electrical characteristics of category 5 make it less susceptible to electrical interference than lower categories.

A characteristic of a network system that allows a computer to send data to any other computer at any time. Connectionless networks are analogous to a postal system in which each letter carries the address of the recipient; letters can be sent at any time.
A form of addressing used by IPv6 in which a set of computers is assigned one address; a datagram sent to the address can be delivered to any one of the computers in the set.

A popular Local Area Network technology that uses a shared bus topology and CSMA/CD access. Basic Ethernet operates at 10 Mbps, Fast Ethernet operates at 100 Mbps, and Gigabit Ethernet operates at 1000 Mbps (i.e., 1 Gbps).

A general concept that refers to separating information received over a common communication channel into its original components. Demultiplexing occurs both in hardware (i.e., electrical signals can be demultiplexed) and in software (i.e., protocol software can demultiplex incoming messages and pass each to the correct application program).
The name applied to cable television systems. CATV technology uses frequency division multiplexing to propagate multiple television channels over a single cable simultaneously.

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking. Note: the acronym CO is also used to refer to a telephone company Central Office.
The IEEE standard for Logical Link Control, Ethernet, Token Ring and Wi-Fi wireless network.
The service used by ATM to transfer an audio or video stream. Data is sent at a steady rate.
A protocol technique in which data is changed by inserting additional bytes to distinguish between data values and packet control values (i.e. headers).
A protocol for propagating multicast routing information.
Term applied to any route propagation protocol used to transfer routing information within a single Autonomous Systems.
A technique IPv6 uses to abbreviate hexadecimal colon notation by replacing a sequence of zeroes with a pair of colons.
The protocol an application uses to send data over an ATM network. AAL5, which is part of the ATM stack, accepts and delivers large packets of data (up to 64K bytes).

question.text: CCITT (Consultative Committee on International Telephone and Telegraph)

answers.answer: A set of packets transmitted back to back. Packet traffic tends to be bursty.
The former name of the ITU.

A protocol that a computer uses when it first starts to obtain information needed to configure the protocol software. BOOTP uses IP and UDP to broadcast a request and receive a response before IP has been completely configured.
A protocol that allows a sender to choose authentication or confidentiality for each datagram.
The time a network interface waits before it can access a shared network.
The technical name for fast Ethernet (100 Mbps).
A small, fixed size packet (e.g., ATM networks send 48-octet cells).
The term telephone companies use to denote a channel configured to handle data. ISDN includes D channel service.
A pejorative term used to refer to the 10% header overhead introduced by ATM.

A characteristic of a network system that allows a computer to send data to any other computer at any time. Connectionless networks are analogous to a postal system in which each letter carries the address of the recipient; letters can be sent at any time.
The automated system used to translate computer names into equivalent IP addresses. A DNS server responds to a query by looking up the name and returning the address.

When two programs communicate over a network, a client is the one that initiates communication, while the program that waits to be contacted is a server. A given program can act as a server for one service and a client for another.
A technology used to create dynamic World Wide Web documents. CGI programs run on the server computer.

A device attached to the end of a wire or a transmission cable to prevent electrical signals from reflecting back. A bus network such as an Ethernet requires each end of the cable to have a terminator.
The most common form of address translation in which protocol port numbers are translated as well as IP addresses.
An old set of network protocols developed and sold by Apple Computer Corporation.
An Internet service that allows multiple users to communicate by entering text that is displayed on the screens of other participants.

The basic building block of an internet. A router is a computer that attaches to two or more networks and forwards packets according to information found in its routing table. Routers in the Internet run the IP protocol.
A wild-card entry in a routing table. The routing software follows the default route if the table does not contain an explicit route to the destination.
An electronic device that forms the center of a star topology network. A switch uses the destination address in a frame to determine which computer should receive the frame.

A value used to verify that data is not corrupted during transmission. The sender computes a checksum by adding the binary values of the data, and transmits the result in a packet with the data. A receiver computes a checksum over the data received, and compares the value to the checksum in the packet.

The term used to describe a networking technology that uses a large part of the electromagnetic spectrum to achieve higher throughput rates. Usually broadband systems employ frequency division multiplexing to allow multiple, independent communications to proceed simultaneously over a single underlying medium.
The main Exterior Gateway Protocol used in the Internet, BGP provides routing among Autonomous Systems.
The hypermedia system used on the Internet in which a page of information can contain text, images, audio, video clips, and references to other pages.
A multicast routing protocol designed to be used across a set of networks that have many listeners (e.g., across Local Area Networks within an organization).

A protocol that computers use to obtain configuration information. DHCP allows a computer to be assigned an IP address without requiring a manager to configure information about the computer in a server's database.
The IP addressing and routing scheme that replaced classful addressing. CIDR uses a 32-bit address mask to denote the boundary between the prefix and suffix of an IP address.

A document stored on a World Wide Web server that is the starting point for obtaining information about a particular individual, company, group, or topic. A homepage can contain pointers to. additional pages of related information or to homepages for other topics.
An alternative to packet switching in which the network hardware forms a circuit between two communicating endpoints. The original telephone network used circuit switching.

A programming language defined by Sun Microsystems used to create active World Wide Web documents. Java programs are compiled into a bytecode representation. After a browser loads a Java program, the program runs locally to control the display.
The source form used for documents on the World Wide Web. HTML embeds commands that determine formatting along with the text to be displayed (e.g., to move to a new line or indent text).
A 32-bit value that specifies how an IP address is divided into network and host portions. Address bits not covered by the mask correspond to the host portion. Also called a subnet mask.
A standard for representing data. The SNMP protocol uses ASN.l to represent object names.
The global Internet that uses TCP/IP protocols.
The TCP/IP protocol that provides application programs with connectionless communication service.
Characteristic of a network in which each transmission is independent. The alternative to connectionless networking is connection-oriented networking.
A multicast routing protocol designed to be used across a set of networks that have many listeners (e.g., across Local Area Networks within an organization).
A type of service offered by ATM.

Characteristic of the original IP addressing scheme in which unicast addresses were divided into three primary classes. The class of an address determines the division between the prefix and suffix in the address.

A value used to verify that data is not corrupted during transmission. The sender computes a checksum by adding the binary values of the data, and transmits the result in a packet with the data. A receiver computes a checksum over the data received, and compares the value to the checksum in the packet.
The version of IP currently used in the Internet. IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses.
The conventional telephone network, including mechanisms for call setup and accounting.
A height for communication satellites in which one orbit takes approximately 90 minutes.
Characteristic of the current IP addressing scheme in which a 32-bit address mask is used to determine the division between the prefix and suffix of an IP address.

When two programs communicate over a network, a client is the one that initiates communication, while the program that waits to be contacted is a server. A given program can act as a server for one service and a client for another.
The type of connector used with thin wire Ethernet.
A specific protocol that has been chosen by the IETF as a successor to IPv4. IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses.

A cable that contains one (or more) twisted pairs of wire surrounded by a heavy metal shield similar to the shield that surrounds a single wire in a coaxial cable. The shield protects the inner pairs of wires from electrical interference.
A protocol developed by the IETF that provides signaling for IP telephony systems.
A field in an LLC header that specifies which organization assigned the numbers used for type information.
A set of tools that helps a programmer build client-server software. Each middleware technology is designed for a specific programming language.
The method of interaction used when two application programs communicate over a network. A server application waits at a known address, and a client application contacts the server.
A protocol that allows a sender to choose authentication or confidentiality for each datagram.

Characteristic of a mechanism used to share a communication medium among multiple senders in which each sender is assigned a unique frequency or channel. Because they use separate frequencies, the simultaneous transmissions do not interfere with one another.
A form of addressing used by IPv6 in which a set of computers is assigned one address; a datagram sent to the address can be delivered to any one of the computers in the set.
A message used for testing and debugging. An ICMP echo reply is returned in answer to an ICMP echo request message. The ping program receives echo replies.
A technology used to control digital cable modems and allow a user to select content.

A technology to deliver digital information at high-speed over the same twisted pair wiring used to deliver telephone service. The downstream bit rate is higher than the upstream rate because most subscribers retrieve much more information than they send.

The TCP/IP protocol that provides application programs with access to a connection-oriented communication service. TCP offers reliable, flow-controlled delivery. More important TCP accommodates changing conditions in the Internet by adapting its retransmission scheme.
Any mechanism that encapsulates a packet in a high-level protocol for transmission.

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking. Note: the acronym CO is also used to refer to a telephone company Central Office.
Any communication network that accepts and delivers individual packets of information. Most modern networks are packet switching.
A problem in wireless networks in which a third party can hear one but not both of a pair of communicating stations.
A standard for the optical fiber encoding used in popular telephone company digital circuits. An OC-3 circuit operates at 155.520 Mbps.

A network that uses technology designed to span a large geographic area. For example, a satellite network is a WAN because a satellite can relay communication across an entire continent. WANs have higher propagation delay than LANs or MANs.
A form of network attack in which a site is flooded with so many packets (usually incorrect or fictitious requests) that the site cannot respond to legitimate requests.
An addressing scheme in which part of an address gives information about the location. For example, a telephone number is hierarchical because it begins with an area code followed by an exchange.

A type of cable used for computer networks as. well as for. cable television. The name arises from the structure in which a metal shield surrounds a center wire. The shield protects the signal on the inner wire- from electrical interference.

A document stored on a World Wide Web server that is the starting point for obtaining information about a particular individual, company, group, or topic. A homepage can contain pointers to. additional pages of related information or to homepages for other topics.
Any mechanism that encapsulates a packet in a high-level protocol for transmission.
The technique in which information to be sent is placed inside the data area of a packet or frame. A packet from one protocol can be encapsulated in another (e.g., ICMP can be encapsulated in IP).
A dynamic Web page technology that allows items in a page to come from a conventional database. The server interprets SQL queries embedded in each page whenever the page is requested.
Synonym for NIC.
The documents in which standards for TCP/IP protocols are published.
A hardware device that plugs into a computer and connects the computer to a network. Often called a network adapter.
An event that occurs on a CSMA/CD network when two stations attempt to transmit simultaneously. The signals interfere with each other, forcing the two stations to back off and try again.
The syntactic notation used to express an IPv6 address.
A technology developed by the telephone companies to provide high speed digital service over local loop wiring.
A hardware unit used with IP telephony to handle conference calls.
A modem that can send and receive information by modulating a radio frequency carrier. RF modems are used in wireless network technologies.
The name applied to cable television systems. CATV technology uses frequency division multiplexing to propagate multiple television channels over a single cable simultaneously.

A condition in which,.each packet sent through a network experiences excessive delay because the network is overrun with packets. Unless protocol software detects congestion and reduces the rate at which packets are sent, a network can experience congestion collapse.

A term that telephone companies use to refer to the wiring between the central office and a subscriber (e.g., an individual business or residence). A variety of technologies have been developed to provide high-speed digital services over existing local loop wiring.

A reference to a cable in which the wire used to transmit on one end connects to the wire used to receive on the other, and vice-versa. The numbers 2 and 3 refer to the transmit and receive pins on a DB-25 connector.
The organization that sets policy for assignment of Internet addresses and domain names.
The term telephone companies use to denote a channel configured to handle data. ISDN includes D channel service.
