The procedure a receiver uses to recreate a copy of an original datagram from the fragments that arrive.
Wiring in which pairs of wires are twisted together to minimize interference, but no other shielding is provided.
An object-oriented middleware technology.

An electronic device that connects a leased digital data circuit to computer equipment. The DSU/CSU translates between the digital format used by the telephone companies and the format used by the computer industry.
Characteristic of any protocol or function that operates on the original source and ultimate destination, but not on intermediate computers (e.g., not on routers).
A set of procedures that an application program can use to communicate across a network. The name arises because the set includes a socket procedure that must be called to establish communication.
The time required to send a signal across a network. The term comes from electrical engineering terminology, and describes an electrical signal propagating down a wire.
An algorithm that bridges use when they boot to detect and break cycles.

A technique that a protocol can use to improve throughput by allowing a sender to transmit additional packets before receiving any acknowledgement. A receiver tells a sender how many packets can be sent at one time (called a window size).

A mode in which a computer connected to a shared network captures all packets, including packets destined for other computers. Promiscuous mode is useful for network monitoring, but presents a security risk for a production network. Many standard interfaces allow promiscuous mode.
The documents in which standards for TCP/IP protocols are published.
A Wide Area Network technology that provides connection-oriented service.
An inexpensive IP router that has sufficient capacity for a residence or small office.
A set of networks connected by routers that are configured to pass traffic among any computers attached to networks in the set. Most internets use TCP/IP protocols.
An interpretive language used for active World Wide Web documents. Because they are kept in source form, JavaScript programs can be integrated with text in a World Wide Web page.
The piece of equipment that the telephone company supplies to terminate a digital circuit.
A standard for digital encoding used by the telephone companies.
A protocol used to transfer a complete file from ope computer to another.
A parity bit added to a unit of data, usually each character, to make the number of 1 bits even. A receiver checks the parity to determine whether data has been corrupted during transmission.

An address in a packet that specifies the computer that sent the packet. In a hardware frame, the source address must be a hardware address. In an IP datagram, the source address must be an IP address.

A characteristic of a network system that allows a computer to send data to any other computer at any time. Connectionless networks are analogous to a postal system in which each letter carries the address of the recipient; letters can be sent at any time.
A server that contains complete routing information for the global Internet. All route servers together form the routing arbiter system.
A multicast routing protocol designed to be used across a set of networks that have many listeners (e.g., across Local Area Networks within an organization).

A connection from one computer to another through a connection-oriented network. A PVC is permanent in the sense that it survives computer reboots or power cycles; a PVC is virtual because it is achieved by placing routes in routing tables, not by establishing physical wires. ATM expands the acronym to Permanent Virtual Channel.
A general link-status algorithm that routers can use to compute routes.
A telephone company term for the boundary between communication facilities owned by the telephone company and facilities owned by a private organization.
A protocol used to transfer a file from one computer to another. TFTP is simpler than FTP, but does not have as much capability.
A form of delivery in which one copy of a packet is delivered to each computer on a network.

A transmission technique used to avoid interference and achieve higher throughput. Instead of a single carrier frequency, a sender and receiver agree to use a set of frequencies, either at the same time or by changing from one to another. The technique is especially important for wireless networks.
The standard for signaling (i.e., call setup and termination) used in the PSTN.
The maximum amount of data that can be sent along the path from a source to a destination in one packet. Technically, the path MTU is the minimum MTU of any network along the path.
The version of IP currently used in the Internet. IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses.
The protocol that IP uses to report errors and exceptions. ICMP also includes informational messages used by programs like ping.
The technical name for gigabit Ethernet.
A subtree of the computer naming hierarchy used in the Internet. For example, commercial organizations have names registered under the .com domain.

A programming language defined by Sun Microsystems used to create active World Wide Web documents. Java programs are compiled into a bytecode representation. After a browser loads a Java program, the program runs locally to control the display.
An application-layer technology that allows remote login. Ssh is similar to TELNET except that ssh uses encryption to guarantee confidentiality.
A standard for representing data. The SNMP protocol uses ASN.l to represent object names.
An encryption technology that provides confidentiality for data sent over a TCP connection. SSL is used with Web transfers that involve commerce (e.g., sending a credit card number).
A small IP datagram produced by fragmentation.
A CSMA network that has the capability to detect errors that result when multiple stations transmit simultaneously.
A type of service offered by ATM.
An amount of data that a receiver is willing to accept at any time. Window size can be measured in packets or in bytes.

A condition in which,.each packet sent through a network experiences excessive delay because the network is overrun with packets. Unless protocol software detects congestion and reduces the rate at which packets are sent, a network can experience congestion collapse.
An informal- term for an implementation of a protocol suite. The term arises because a protocol layering diagram shows protocols in a vertical "stack".
A small integer used to identify a specific application program on a remote computer. Transport protocols like TCP assign a unique port number to each service (e.g., e-mail uses port 25).

Characteristic of a network that uses packet switches to forward packets. The name arises because each switch along a path to the destination receives a packet and temporarily stores the packet in. memory. Meanwhile the switch continuously selects a packet from the queue in memory, routes the packet, and then transmits the packet to the appropriate next hop.
A network architecture that consists of a central hub to which all computers connect. Star topologies are often used with Local Area Networks (e.g., twisted pair Ethernet).

An electronic device that connects a leased digital data circuit to computer equipment. The DSU/CSU translates between the digital format used by the telephone companies and the format used by the computer industry.

A dynamic Web page technology. Originally named Perl Helper Pages, the expansion has been changed to the recursive form listed here. Whenever a PHP page is requested, the Web server invokes the PHP preprocessor to run a script (usually written in Perl) that generates the final form of the page.
A server that is designed so the action performed for a given request depends on the prior history of requests.
The most common form of address translation in which protocol port numbers are translated as well as IP addresses.
An algorithm that bridges use when they boot to detect and break cycles.
A specification language used with a remote procedure call mechanism.
A server that handles each request independently. Most servers are designed to be as stateless as possible.
A standard for digital encoding used by the telephone companies.
A ring topology network that uses token passing for access control. The phrase also applies to an older token passing ring topology defined by IBM Corporation.
A page of information available on the World Wide Web. The contents of a static document do not change until the author places new information in the document.
An algorithm for computing shortest paths in a graph. Routing protocols use Dijkstra's algorithm to compute optimal routes.

A conceptual framework used to explain the purpose and interaction among a set of protocols. Layering is primarily beneficial to protocol designers; once implemented, protocols can be used without understanding layering.
A security mechanism that watches packets arriving at a site and detects attacks.
An informal- term for an implementation of a protocol suite. The term arises because a protocol layering diagram shows protocols in a vertical "stack".
A set of standards developed by telephone companies for high-speed digital circuits.

A variant of STDM that only services a given source when the source has something to send. The chief advantage of statistical multiplexing arises because it never leaves the communication channel idle while a source has something to send.
A group of networks and routers under one administrative authority. For routing purposes, the Internet is divided into Autonomous Systems.
The largest amount of data that can be sent across a given network in a single packet. Each network technology defines an MTU (e.g., the MTU of an Ethernet is 1500 octets).

A communication between two computers in which data can flow in only one direction at a given time. Half-duplex transmission requires less hardware than full- duplex transmission because a single, shared physical medium can be used for all communication.
Any time-division multiplexing mechanism that proceeds round-robin among all sources. The acronym is also expanded to Slotted Time Division Multiplexing.
An ITU-standard for a family of protocols used with IP telephony (VoIP).
The protocol suite used in the Internet. Although the suite contains many protocols, TCP and IP are two of the most important.

Characteristic of a network that uses packet switches to forward packets. The name arises because each switch along a path to the destination receives a packet and temporarily stores the packet in. memory. Meanwhile the switch continuously selects a packet from the queue in memory, routes the packet, and then transmits the packet to the appropriate next hop.
A telephone company term for the mechanisms that provide call setup and termination.
A set of protocols designed to deliver and display pages of information on small, portable wireless devices such as portable telephones and pagers.
A set of standards adopted by common carriers for high-speed digital circuits. STS-1 operates at 51.840 Mbps; STS-n runs at n times that bit rate.

The term used to describe a networking technology that uses a large part of the electromagnetic spectrum to achieve higher throughput rates. Usually broadband systems employ frequency division multiplexing to allow multiple, independent communications to proceed simultaneously over a single underlying medium.
Term used informally to define a computer that only has one network interface, but has been configured to behave like a router. One-armed routers are often used with Network Address Translation.
A popular application in which a user or computer sends a memo to one or more recipients.

A term used to express the idea that communication tends to follow patterns. Spatial locality of reference means that a computer is more likely to communicate with a nearby computer than a distant computer, and temporal locality of reference means that a computer is more likely to communicate with the same computer repeatedly than to communicate with a new computer each time.
The hypermedia system used on the Internet in which a page of information can contain text, images, audio, video clips, and references to other pages.
An older LAN technology that uses fiber optics to interconnect stations in a ring topology.
An extension of the original IP addressing scheme in which an organization uses a single IP prefix for multiple physical networks.
An older LAN technology that uses fiber optics to interconnect stations in a ring topology.
The IEEE standard for Logical Link Control, Ethernet, Token Ring and Wi-Fi wireless network.

A technology that provides connectivity for many computers at a site through a single valid IP address. NAT rewrites the header of each outgoing and incoming datagram to replace the internal address with the globally valid IP address and vice versa.
A synonym for address mask.

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking.
The required header found at the beginning of an IPv6 datagram.

A connection from one computer to another through a connection-oriented network. An SVC is virtual because it is achieved by placing routes in routing tables, not by establishing physical wires; an SVC is switched because it can be created on demand analogous to a telephone call. ATM expands the acronym to Switched Virtual Channel.
A set of protocols designed to deliver and display pages of information on small, portable wireless devices such as portable telephones and pagers.

When two programs communicate over a network, a client is the one that initiates communication, while a server is the program that waits to be contacted. A given program can act as a server for one service and a client for another.
An electronic device that forms the center of a star topology network. A switch uses the destination address in a frame to determine which computer should receive the frame.
An event that occurs on a CSMA/CD network when two stations attempt to transmit simultaneously. The signals interfere with each other, forcing the two stations to back off and try again.
An extension of the original IP addressing scheme in which an organization uses a single IP prefix for multiple physical networks.
A term used for IP telephony. VoIP includes call setup and termination as well as the transmission of digitized audio.
Any network that uses switches instead of routers. Usually, switching implies connection-oriented technology, ATM is an example of a technology that uses switching.
A range of frequencies used for sending radio signals through the air (e.g., from a commercial radio station). Wireless network technologies use RF.
A form of NAT proposed by cable TV companies.
A standard that assigns unique values to 128 characters, including upper and lower case letters, digits, punctuation, and control characters. Details can be found in Appendix 2.
A 5-layer model that describes the conceptual purpose of protocols in the TCP/IP protocol suite.

A connection from one computer to another through a connection-oriented network. An SVC is virtual because it is achieved by placing routes in routing tables, not by establishing physical wires; an SVC is switched because it can be created on demand analogous to a telephone call. ATM expands the acronym to Switched Virtual Channel.

A general term used to describe the operation of a switch. Because it is associated with hardware, switching is usually higher speed than routing. Also, switching differs from routing because switching uses the hardware address in a frame.
A set of documents in which a given document can contain text, graphics, video and audio clips as well as embedded references to other documents. World Wide Web pages are hypermedia documents.
An interpretive language used for active World Wide Web documents. Because they are kept in source form, JavaScript programs can be integrated with text in a World Wide Web page.
The initial segment of a TCP transmission. Each side sends a SYN to start a connection. A well-known security attack involves sending a flood of SYN segments.
A multicast routing protocol that extends OSPF to handle multicast.
The time required to send a signal across a network. The term comes from electrical engineering terminology, and describes an electrical signal propagating down a wire.
A short message returned to inform a sender that data has arrived at its intended destination.

Characteristic of any communication system in which the sender must coordinate (i.e., synchronize) with the receiver before sending data. Synchronization is usually handled by having the sending hardware transmit regular pulses when no data is available. The receiver uses the pulses to extract data from the incoming signal.
Synonym for link-status.
The process of changing a carrier wave (usually a sine wave) to encode information. The frequency of the carrier and the modulation technique determine the rate at which data can be sent.

A network diagnostic program that finds the address of all routers between the user's computer and a specified destination. Traceroute sends datagrams with successively larger time-to-live values, and uses ICMP error messages to determine routers along the path.
The designations that telephone companies use for popular point-to-point digital circuits. A T1 circuit operates at 1.544 Mbps; a T3 circuit operates at 44.736 Mbps.
A standard format for storing a graphics image. JPEG images are often used on the World Wide Web. The name is derived from the committee that published the standard.
The type of connector used with twisted pair Ethernet.
The piece of equipment that the telephone company supplies to terminate a digital circuit.
The organization that sets policy for assignment of Internet addresses and domain names.
A modem located at a customer's site (e.g., a residence).

The TCP/IP protocol that provides application programs with access to a connection-oriented communication service. TCP offers reliable, flow-controlled delivery. More important TCP accommodates changing conditions in the Internet by adapting its retransmission scheme.
An alternative to packet switching in which the network hardware forms a circuit between two communicating endpoints. The original telephone network used circuit switching.

The technique used by protocols like IP to forward a packet to its final destination. Although a given router does not contain complete information about the path a datagram will follow, the router does know the next router to which the datagram should be sent.

A term that refers to the amount of variation in delay that a network introduces. A network with zero jitter takes exactly the same amount of time to transfer each packet, while a network with high jitter takes much longer to deliver some packets than others. Jitter is important when sending audio or video, which must arrive at regular intervals.
A markup language used for Web pages that contain audio (typically used with cell phones).
A standard for sending digital information over a cable modem system.
A technique related to NAT that uses segment mapping to join two separate TCP connections.
A markup language used for Web pages that contain audio (typically used with cell phones).
A synonym for network analyzer taken from a popular product.

A generic reference to a set of procedures that an application" program uses to access a service. A network API consists of procedures a program uses to access protocol software; the most well-known is the socket API.
The IP addressing and routing scheme that replaced classful addressing. CIDR uses a 32-bit address mask to denote the boundary between the prefix and suffix of an IP address.
The protocol suite used in the Internet. Although the suite contains many protocols, TCP and IP are two of the most important.
A standard that assigns unique values to 256 characters, including upper and lower case letters, digits, punctuation, and control characters.
Characteristic of a mechanism that allows multiple senders to share a communication medium by taking turns. At any time, only one sender transmits across the channel.
A specification language used with a remote procedure call mechanism.
The path of data transmitted from an earth station to a satellite.

An experimental system used to send multicast data across the Internet. Although MBONE routers multicast locally, they use an IP tunnel to transfer multicast datagrams across the Internet from one site to another.

A device attached to the end of a wire or a transmission cable to prevent electrical signals from reflecting back. A bus network such as an Ethernet requires each end of the cable to have a terminator.
A domain name server that knows the locations of top-level domains such as .com and .edu.
Part of the IEEE LLC/SNAP header used to identify the type of a packet. The entire header is 8 octets, with the LLC portion occupying the first three.
An end-user's computer connected to a network. In an internet, each computer is classified as a host or a router.
A problem in wireless networks in which a third party can hear one but not both of a pair of communicating stations.
A protocol used to transfer a file from one computer to another. TFTP is simpler than FTP, but does not have as much capability.
The group that controls the TCP/IP protocol standards.
A generic reference to any of the services such as ADSL and HDSL that supply broadband data rates over telephone lines.
An informal term used for the original DIX Ethernet.

A generic reference to a set of procedures that an application" program uses to access a service. A network API consists of procedures a program uses to access protocol software; the most well-known is the socket API.
An old set of network protocols developed and sold by Apple Computer Corporation.

A popular Local Area Network technology that uses a shared bus topology and CSMA/CD access. Basic Ethernet operates at 10 Mbps, Fast Ethernet operates at 100 Mbps, and Gigabit Ethernet operates at 1000 Mbps (i.e., 1 Gbps).
A device used to debug network problems or monitor performance. An analyzer captures packets from a network and reports statistics such as the percentage of broadcast traffic.
A synonym for thick wire Ethernet.
A height for communication satellites in which one orbit takes approximately 90 minutes.
A protocol that uses the distance-vector approach to propagate routing information within an Autonomous System.
A hardware device that plugs into a computer and connects the computer to a network. Often called a network adapter.
The touch tone encoding used with telephones.
An informal term used for the version of Ethernet that uses thinner coaxial cable.
A telephone company term for the boundary between communication facilities owned by the telephone company and facilities owned by a private organization.
A synonym for thin wire Ethernet.
A synonym for hardware address.
The piece of equipment that the telephone company supplies to terminate a digital circuit.
The generic name used during early discussions of a new protocol to succeed IPv4. Researchers proposed several possible protocols for IPng.
A set of procedures that an application program can use to communicate across a network. The name arises because the set includes a socket procedure that must be called to establish communication.

A mechanism used in an ATM network to deliver a copy of data to multiple destinations. A point-to-multipoint circuit in a connection-oriented network provides functionality equivalent to multicasting in a connectionless network.
A measure of the capacity of a digital network. The value is given as a ratio of bits transmitted per unit time. In informal situations, the term bandwidth is often used to refer to throughput.
A synonym for address mask.
Any of the domains such as .com, .edu, or .org that form the top level of the domain hierarchy.
A popular application in which a user or computer sends a memo to one or more recipients.
The multicast routing protocol used on the MBONE. DVMRP sends multicast locally, but uses IP-in-IP tunneling to transfer multicast datagrams among sites.
A standard used with RPC to allow heterogeneous computers to exchange character, integer, and floating point values.
A network system in which a satellite broadcasts all packets and allows individual receivers to discard packets intended for other recipients.
The organization responsible for assigning numbers that the TCP/IP protocols use. For example, IANA assigns numeric values used in protocol header fields.
A technique used in ring topology networks to control transmission.
A ring topology network that uses token passing for access control. The phrase also applies to an older token passing ring topology defined by IBM Corporation.
An effort to combine IP with hardware switching (especially ATM) to achieve higher speed.

Term applied to any mechanism that gives statistical guarantees about the service received. QoS mechanisms achieve guarantees by discarding some of the packets from users who do not purchase high-quality service.
A technology that allows an ISP to authenticate dial-up customers.
A term used to describe the general shape of a network. Common topologies include bus, point-to-point, ring, and star.

A cable that contains one (or more) twisted pairs of wire surrounded by a heavy metal shield similar to the shield that surrounds a single wire in a coaxial cable. The shield protects the inner pairs of wires from electrical interference.
An optional header used in the IPv6 protocol.
A small, fixed size packet (e.g., ATM networks send 48-octet cells).

A value used to verify that data is not corrupted during transmission. The sender computes a checksum by adding the binary values of the data, and transmits the result in a packet with the data. A receiver computes a checksum over the data received, and compares the value to the checksum in the packet.
A conceptual model that explains how TCP/IP Internet protocols are designed.

A network diagnostic program that finds the address of all routers between the user's computer and a specified destination. Traceroute sends datagrams with successively larger time-to-live values, and uses ICMP error messages to determine routers along the path.
A field in an IPv6 header that specifies the type of the next item.
The name that Microsoft uses for the traceroute program included with its operating systems.
A protocol technique in which data is changed by inserting additional bytes to distinguish between data values and packet control values (i.e. headers).
A server that handles each request independently. Most servers are designed to be as stateless as possible.

An application gateway that is part of a firewall. A secure proxy allows users on one side of the firewall to access a specific service on the other side of the firewall according to the organization's security policy.

When two programs communicate over a network, a client is the one that initiates communication, while the program that waits to be contacted is a server. A given program can act as a server for one service and a client for another.
The multicast routing protocol used on the MBONE. DVMRP sends multicast locally, but uses IP-in-IP tunneling to transfer multicast datagrams among sites.
The protocol an application uses to send data over an ATM network. AAL5, which is part of the ATM stack, accepts and delivers large packets of data (up to 64K bytes).
An electronic device that connects the Network Interface Card in a computer to a physical medium. Transceivers are used with thick wire Ethernet.
Any change introduced as data passes across a network. Transmission errors can be caused by electrical interference or hardware that malfunctions.

A network that uses technology designed to span a small geographic area. For example, an Ethernet is a LAN technology suitable for use in a single building. LANs have lower propagation delay than WANs or MANs.
The algorithm bridges use to avoid a loop.

Characteristic of the original IP addressing scheme in which unicast addresses were divided into three primary classes. The class of an address determines the division between the prefix and suffix in the address.

A term with more than one meaning. Telephone companies use the term to refer to large-capacity circuits that form the main interconnect of the telephone network (e.g., between cities). Cable television companies use the term to refer to the high- capacity coaxial cables used to connect the cable company and neighborhood concentration points; a trunk circuit can be up to fifteen miles long.
The IEEE standard for Logical Link Control, Ethernet, Token Ring and Wi-Fi wireless network.
A field in an IPv6 header that specifies the type of the next item.
The rate at which data can be transmitted across a network. The number of bits per second may differ from the baud rate because more than one bit can be encoded in a single baud.

A general concept that refers to combining independent sources of information into a form that can be transmitted over a single communication channel. Multiplexing can occur both in hardware (i.e., electrical signals can be multiplexed) and in software (i.e., protocol software can "accept messages sent by multiple application programs and send them over a single network to different destinations).
A generic reference to any of the services such as ADSL and HDSL that supply broadband data rates over telephone lines.
A value found in the header of an IP datagram. Each router decrements the TTL value. If the TTL reaches zero, the router discards the datagram and sends an ICMP error message to the source.
An end-user's computer connected to a network. In an internet, each computer is classified as a host or a router.
A type of wiring needed for twisted pair Ethernet. The. electrical characteristics of category 5 make it less susceptible to electrical interference than lower categories.

The basic technique protocols use to achieve reliable delivery. The receiving protocol returns an acknowledgement when a packet arrives. After transmitting a packet, the sender starts a timer. If the acknowledgement does not arrive before the timer expires, the sender retransmits the packet.

A connection from one computer to another through a connection-oriented network. An SVC is virtual because it is achieved by placing routes in routing tables, not by establishing physical wires; an SVC is switched because it can be created on demand analogous to a telephone call. ATM expands the acronym to Switched Virtual Channel.
Any mechanism that encapsulates a packet in a high-level protocol for transmission.

A small value a Web server passes to a browser in a reply to help the server identify the user. A browser returns the cookie when sending subsequent requests from the user to the server that issued the cookie.
A form of wiring in which a pair of wires is wrapped around one another again and again. Twisting two wires reduces their susceptibility to electrical interference.

A program that acts as a proxy to provide service indirectly. Application gateways are used in Internet firewalls to allow employees in an organization to access the Internet according to the organization's security policy.

A cable that contains one (or more) twisted pairs of wire surrounded by a heavy metal shield similar to the shield that surrounds a single wire in a coaxial cable. The shield protects the inner pairs of wires from electrical interference.
A set of standards developed by telephone companies for high-speed digital circuits.

A program that acts as a proxy to provide service indirectly. Application gateways are used in Internet firewalls to allow employees in an organization to access the Internet according to the organization's security policy.
A set of protocols that work together to provide a seamless communication system. Each protocol handles a subset of all possible details. The Internet uses the TCP/IP protocol suite.
A directory service used with middleware.
The final segment of a TCP transmission. Each side sends a FIN to close the connection.
The TCP/IP protocol that provides application programs with connectionless communication service.
The technical name of the standard used for serial data connections such as those between a keyboard and a computer. The standard defines such details as the voltage used to represent a 1 and a 0.
The generic name used during early discussions of a new protocol to succeed IPv4. Researchers proposed several possible protocols for IPng.

The basic building block of an internet. A router is a computer that attaches to two or more networks and forwards packets according to information found in its routing table. Routers in the Internet run the IP protocol.
The name of a popular program that implements Domain Name Server functionality.
A pejorative term used to refer to the 10% header overhead introduced by ATM.

A form of packet delivery in which each computer is assigned a unique address. When a packet is sent to a unicast address, exactly one copy of the packet is delivered to the computer to which the address corresponds. Unicast delivery is the most common type.
The path of data transmitted from an earth station to a satellite.
The path of data from the Internet to a residential customer. The term is often used with DSL or cable modem technologies.
A network architecture in which all computers attach to a shared medium, often a single cable. The bus architecture is mainly used for Local Area Networks.
A standard format for storing a graphics image. GIF images are especially popular on the World Wide Web.
The path of data from a residential customer to the Internet. The term is often used with DSL or cable modem technologies.
A standard for sending digital information over a cable modem system.
A 32-bit value that specifies how an IP address is divided into network and host portions. Address bits not covered by the mask correspond to the host portion. Also called a subnet mask.
A broadcast to all computers on a remote network achieved by sending a single copy of the packet to the remote network and broadcasting the packet when it arrives. TCP/IP supports directed broadcast.
A synonym for network analyzer.
An interpretive language used for active World Wide Web documents. Because they are kept in source form, JavaScript programs can be integrated with text in a World Wide Web page.
A syntactic form used to identify a page of information on the World Wide Web.
An electronic device that connects the Network Interface Card in a computer to a physical medium. Transceivers are used with thick wire Ethernet.
A dynamic Web page technology closely linked to Microsoft's Web server. The server interprets Visual Basic code that is embedded in each page whenever the page is requested.
Glass fiber used in computer networks. The chief advantage of optical fiber over copper wire is that fiber supports higher bandwidth.
The IP addressing and routing scheme that replaced classful addressing. CIDR uses a 32-bit address mask to denote the boundary between the prefix and suffix of an IP address.
Wiring in which pairs of wires are twisted together to minimize interference, but no other shielding is provided.
The technique used with bus architecture networks in which computers attached to the common bus check for the presence of a carrier before transmitting.
A table used by routing software to determine the next hop for a packet. A routing table is kept in a router's memory.
The service used by ATM to transfer data for. which the data rate changes oyer time.
A single piece of cable that forms a bus network. Multiple segments can be connected by bridges or routers. A hub simulates a single segment.
The service used by ATM to transfer an audio or video stream. Data is sent at a steady rate.
A replacement for WEP.

A connection from one computer to another through a connection-oriented network. The term virtual arises because the circuit is achieved by placing routes in routing tables, not by establishing physical wires. Also called a virtual channel.
A modem used to send digital information over the coaxial cables used for cable television,

A type of physical connector used with computers and communication equipment. The number immediately following the dash specifies the number of pins. For example, DB-9, DB-15, and DB-25 connectors have 9, 15, and 25 pins.
A set of documents in which a given document can contain text, graphics, video and audio clips as well as embedded references to other documents. World Wide Web pages are hypermedia documents.

A communication between two computers in which data can flow in only one direction at a given time. Half-duplex transmission requires less hardware than full- duplex transmission because a single, shared physical medium can be used for all communication.
The original name for distance-vector.
A multicast routing protocol that extends OSPF to handle multicast.
A synonym for virtual circuit. The term virtual channel is used with technologies such as ATM.
The main Exterior Gateway Protocol used in the Internet, BGP provides routing among Autonomous Systems.

A programming language defined by Sun Microsystems used to create active World Wide Web documents. Java programs are compiled into a bytecode representation. After a browser loads a Java program, the program runs locally to control the display.
A- connection-oriented technology defined by the ITU and the ATM Forum. At the lowest level, ATM sends data in fixed cells with 48 octets of data per cell.

A term that refers to the amount of variation in delay that a network introduces. A network with zero jitter takes exactly the same amount of time to transfer each packet, while a network with high jitter takes much longer to deliver some packets than others. Jitter is important when sending audio or video, which must arrive at regular intervals.

A replacement for the existing cable television infrastructure that uses optical fiber trunks with coaxial cable connections to each subscriber and provides two-way digital information transfer in addition to television signals.
A term used for IP telephony. VoIP includes call setup and termination as well as the transmission of digitized audio.
A term used with cable television that refers to the wiring between a neighborhood concentration point and individual subscribers. A feeder circuit is less than two miles long.

A computer program that accesses and displays information from the World Wide Web. A browser contains multiple application programs, and uses an object's name to determine which application should be used to access the object.
A binary value used in an ATM network to identify a particular connection. Each switch along a path rewrites the VPI/VCI.
The documents in which standards for TCP/IP protocols are published.
A modem at a telephone company or cable office.
A protocol for propagating multicast routing information.
A synonym for World Wide Web.
A technology that uses encryption and IP tunneling to allow a multi-site organization to use low-cost Internet connections among sites but still keep data confidential.
A markup language used for Web pages that contain audio (typically used with cell phones).

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking.
A field in an IPv6 header that specifies the type of the next item.
A UNIX program that performs multicast routing. Mrouted implements the DVMRP protocol, and is used in the MBONE.

A network that uses technology designed to span a large geographic area. For example, a satellite network is a WAN because a satellite can relay communication across an entire continent. WANs have higher propagation delay than LANs or MANs.
Characteristic of a network in which each transmission is independent. The alternative to connectionless networking is connection-oriented networking.

A network that uses technology designed to span a small geographic area. For example, an Ethernet is a LAN technology suitable for use in a single building. LANs have lower propagation delay than WANs or MANs.
A form of delivery in which one copy of a packet is delivered to each computer on a network.
A set of protocols designed to deliver and display pages of information on small, portable wireless devices such as portable telephones and pagers.
A protocol that allows a sender to choose authentication or confidentiality for each datagram.

A communication between two computers in which data can flow in only one direction at a given time. Half-duplex transmission requires less hardware than full- duplex transmission because a single, shared physical medium can be used for all communication.
A wild-card entry in a routing table. The routing software follows the default route if the table does not contain an explicit route to the destination.
A frequency division multiplexing technique applied to optical fiber.
The name of a Linux program that implements Network Address Translation.
A scheme for digital encoding of audio in which successive values represent differences in the sampled wave instead of absolute values.
An amount of data that a receiver is willing to accept at any time. Window size can be measured in packets or in bytes.
A synonym for World Wide Web.
The number of changes in a signal per second. Each change can encode one or more bits of information.
Characteristic of a mechanism that allows multiple senders to share a communication medium by taking turns. At any time, only one sender transmits across the channel.
The syntactic notation used to express a 32-bit IPv4 address. Each octet is written in decimal with a period separating octets.
The area of a packet that contains information about the sender, destination, and contents.
A marketing term invented by an alliance of vendors who sell 802.11 wireless network technology.
The original privacy mechanism that was part of IEEE 802.11 wireless networks. WEP was found to be insufficient.
An ITU-standard for a family of protocols used with IP telephony (VoIP).
A marketing term invented by an alliance of vendors who sell 802.11 wireless network technology.
A dynamic Web page technology closely linked to Microsoft's Web server. The server interprets Visual Basic code that is embedded in each page whenever the page is requested.

An early conceptual model devised by the International Organization for Standardization to specify how a set of protocols work together to provide communication services. The 7-layer model did not include an internet protocol layer.
A general link-status algorithm that routers can use to compute routes.
A synonym for hop count that is used by IPv6.
The organization that sets policy for assignment of Internet addresses and domain names.
An amount of data that a receiver is willing to accept at any time. Window size can be measured in packets or in bytes.
A directory service used with middleware.
A ring topology network that uses token passing for access control. The phrase also applies to an older token passing ring topology defined by IBM Corporation.

The protocol that specifies how a network management station communicates with agent software in remote devices such as routers; the current version is number 3. SNMP defines the format of messages and their meaning.
A networking technology that uses RF communication to interconnect computers over a short distance.

Characteristic of a network in which a connection must be established before data can be sent, and terminated after all data has been transferred. The alternative to connection-oriented networking is connectionless networking.
Any communication network that accepts and delivers individual packets of information. Most modern networks are packet switching.
A CSMA network that has the capability to detect errors that result when multiple stations transmit simultaneously.
A replacement for WEP.
The hypermedia system used on the Internet in which a page of information can contain text, images, audio, video clips, and references to other pages.
The hypermedia system used on the Internet in which a page of information can contain text, images, audio, video clips, and references to other pages.
A unit of data transfer equal to 10^6 bps.
A standard format for storing a graphics image. GIF images are especially popular on the World Wide Web.
A leased circuit that operates slower than T1 speed. Typically, fractional T1 means 64 Kbps.
The organization that sets policy for assignment of Internet addresses and domain names.
An older LAN technology that uses fiber optics to interconnect stations in a ring topology.

An algorithm that routers use to compute optimal routes to each destination. Periodically, each router receives routing information from neighboring routers. A router replaces a current route if a lower cost route becomes available.
A standard used with RPC to allow heterogeneous computers to exchange character, integer, and floating point values.
The technical name for 10 Mbps twisted pair Ethernet.
The generic name used during early discussions of a new protocol to succeed IPv4. Researchers proposed several possible protocols for IPng.

A markup language that is used primarily for exchange of data between two computer programs. An XML document contains embedded tags that give names for fields in the data. Unlike HTML, XML does not specify formatting information.
A hardware device that plugs into a computer and connects the computer to a network. Often called a network adapter.
A cookie that a browser holds in memory. Because it is kept in memory instead of on disk, a session cookie only persists while the browser is running.
A technique IPv6 uses to abbreviate hexadecimal colon notation by replacing a sequence of zeroes with a pair of colons.
A set of named items that an SNMP agent understands. To monitor or control a remote computer, a manager must fetch or store values to MIB variables.

A technology that provides connectivity for many computers at a site through a single valid IP address. NAT rewrites the header of each outgoing and incoming datagram to replace the internal address with the globally valid IP address and vice versa.
